inscription: Left lower center, in black: 徽宗皇帝図以画之 (Painted after a work by the Emperor Huizong)
markings: LLC, two seals, in red: {Kentei};  東牛斎 {Togyūsai}
medium: Hanging scroll; ink and color on paper
text: This scene exemplifies the swan-hunt theme in Chinese painting, which was first developed by the Khitan people during the Liao dynasty (907–1125) and later adopted as a prominent visual motif by the Jurchen in the Jin dynasty (1115–1234). The inscription on the left states that Yoshida Rankō painted it after a work by the Emperor Huizong (1082–1135) of the Song dynasty. The painting he saw, or maybe a copy, was sold at a Christie’s auction in New York in 2015.
title: Gyrfalcon Attacking a Swan, after Emperor Huizong
